text: PATIENT: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the –

text: FAMILY MEMBER: Ohh!
DOCTOR: So it isn’t like he stands there and they only shoot it up like a bone injection.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
DOCTOR: Uhn-uhn. You get an intravenous you know little catheter.
PATIENT: And that’s going to be in me for six months.
DOCTOR: Yeah, like they give it to you - it’s like one minute, and you’re done for the month.
FAMILY MEMBER: Does he have to keep that catheter in there for the whole month?
DOCTOR: No.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh good.
DOCTOR: Like you put it in (makes mimicking sound)
FAMILY MEMBER: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking.
DOCTOR: At this moment, I wouldn’t; I’d just chill out. Time to just kick back. You’ve moved in; don’t do anything else.

DOCTOR: Why don’t you get on the scooter thing?

DOCTOR: Um hum.
PATIENT: And stay at dad’s until it’s all done.
DOCTOR: So it might be a couple of months.

DOCTOR: Okay. We’ll shoot for less than a month. How about that?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. As we analyze different perceptions of doctors' qualities, understanding your personal experiences with the medical system helps contextualize these ratings. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential.
